I know you like to try and catch all your ideas. I used to too. At work in the amazon warehouse many ideas came to me. and I would run around like a crazy person trying to find a pen and paper to write them down. then at home after a while I ended up having a stack of these ideas. then two stacks and three. then I went for yoga teacher training and learned about aparigraha and wanted to become detached and the feeling I get when an idea comes feels very attached so I wanted to get rid of my stacks of ideas. so I got rid of most of them and kept a few. But now I'm thinking, why do I need to capture every idea? because I'm not the source of them. The source is endless! and if the source wanted me to have an idea at a certain point in time, it would send one, right? so maybe that's how I can remain detached while also being open to receiving ideas. But then again I have nothing to show for any of this yet, while you have much to show for your methods of capturi ng all possible ideas. So maybe I shouldn't have gotten rid of my stacks of ideas. Oh well. The past is the past.

you're right that there are infinite. but the reason i think you need to write them down is because they mostly probably will not come to you at your moment of deliberate songwriting. When you go to work on songwriting, on purpose, and you need ideas, ..... the ideas might not want to come, because they feel they are being watched. Ideas seem to come more readily when you are not expecting. that's why i think it's important to write these down, because this might be your main best source of ideas. Then, the songwriting department just has to learn how to work with ideas that are handed to them, from the list. then there's whole other department called the selecting department, but that's another story entirely

is there a reason that "memory" appears between aaaacv and frenca, then again between frenez and loveqa and yeat again between lovesz and zzzzya in the part of got some money where the 6-letter combinations are scrolling down the screen?

yes. What i would have preferred to do, is to be able to actually create that entire alphabetical phrase list. which i was able to generate quite easily, but the problem we run into, when the list goes into the graphics, .... the list is so long that it actually makes the computer lag, or probably even crash, depending on how you do it. There's literally millions of lines in that text pattern, if it were carried out properly from a to z across all 6 characters. So even though it's just text, it actually is an absurdly unnecessary strain on the memory of the scene, pretty much any way you slice it. And the truth is, in that scene, with the small amount of time it's shown, you'd never see all the lines. and also, another reason you don't wanna include the whole list is that the scroll direction would become incoherently out of phase. like those car wheels on tv that seem to move slow or backwards or whatever. So it turns out, even just to create the proper looking downward scroll, you need to reduce the number of elements drastically. like pretty much skip 99% of the parts during the fast scroll. But this still does create a continuity problem, because if anyone sees the (maybe 1) frame where you can see it jump from A to L or whatever, .... i feel there's gonna need to be an explanation there. So my explanation is 'memory' as a place holder for the perhaps millions of lines we've skipped

A bit after the release of I'm A Princess, I realized the grammatical meaning of the 3rd verse (the one with the soldiers), and that, grammatically, "dreamed that it's ok" would refer to the soldiers doing the dreaming. I felt a bit disappointed when I realized this because to me it feels very strangely powerful to think of that line as disconnected from the previous lines in a songy sort of way, only being connected to the daydream line by a shared word, and perhaps referring to the narrator doing the dreaming. This interpretation also turns the previous lines from a sentence to just some relevant imagery, which also feels more powerful to me. Do you internalize that verse as one big sentence or as a series of disconnected lines? What did you intend?

i probably intended to find something better, but, i couldn't really figure out how to work the grammar to add up correctly and still get the sound i wanted. by the way, it's "i dreamed that it's ok" although the "i" is probably  not vocalized. Hopefully by the end you've gotten a bit of both

The biggest time gain on "money" was the decision to do the graphics drastically simpler. it was liberating.
